awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Learning and processing mechanisms for singular they/them pronouns
awd_abstract_narration:
The use of the pronoun “they” instead of singular “he” or “she” to refer to a lone individual has met with mixed acceptance for a variety of purposes and can be challenging for some listeners and speakers despite the fact that, historically, singular-they is well entrenched in the language. For example, many people who don't intend to misgender others still make errors in their actual language production. Errors are particularly common with singular they, which is becoming more common and more accepted (46% of younger Americans in 2021 know someone who uses they/them pronouns, up from 32% in 2018), but is still new to many speakers. This project asks why errors like these occur, and tests learning strategies and speech production outcomes.

This project draws on sentence processing, speech production, perspective-taking, and error-based learning approaches to ask novel questions about mechanisms of language learning and production. Building on promising preliminary data, the proposed experiments investigate how difficulties with singular they arise during language processing, how choices between alternative pronouns are affected by context, and what strategies support learning to remember people’s stated pronouns and fluently produce singular they. De-identified data and code will be made publicly available, along with study pre-registrations. In addition to informing evidence-based best practices for reducing misgendering, the findings of the proposed studies will advance understanding of language learning and speech production.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This dissertation investigated the language processing mechanisms involved in learning to comprehend and produce 3rd person pronouns, with the goals of extending existing psycholinguistics models to explain the cognitive mechanisms that can account for how these pronouns are produced and processed in naturalistic contexts. A series of experiments were conducted as a part of the dissertation, examining how people learn and use 3rd person pronouns, including a study looking at production of pronouns and a study looking at comprehension of pronouns using eye-tracking. We use a series of programmatic experiments to examine the cognitive phenomena underlying the processes of learning to use and understand pronouns, using multiple experimental techniques and measures. One line of experiments investigated the online comprehension of 3rd person pronouns including he, she, and they using a version of the visual world paradigm. This study found that in a context where listeners can come to expect that he, she, or they will co-refer with certain characters, listeners are able to use they to identify the referent, but to a lesser degree than with he or she. This processing pattern resembles the similar cognitive processes seen with 3rd person pronoun processing in adult second language learners and in children, which opens up a number of research questions about the cognitive mechanisms that support the interpretation of various 3rd person pronouns as co-referring with specific singular referents. Unlike with 3rd person he and she pronouns, they did not show an order-of-mention effect (where listeners treat the pronoun as more likely to refer to the character mentioned first). This finding points to different discourse processing strategies for they compared to he and she. A second line of experiments investigated spoken production use of 3rd person pronouns in contexts where he, she, and they were in the mix (one of the few psycholinguistics experiments doing so). Accuracy in producing these pronouns was high across the board, and nametags and character introductions significantly improved accuracy, pointing to get-to-know you tasks as a successful way to help people produce pronouns accurately. In sum, this project used sentence processing, speech production, perspective-taking, and error-based learning approaches to ask novel questions about mechanisms of language learning and production. The de-identified data and code have been made publicly available, along with study pre-registrations. The project provided training for the graduate student and two undergraduate students who were trained in best research practices, including the ethical conduct of research, data collection, data curation, and data analysis, as well as in writing about scientific research. The de-identified data and commented code resulting from this work were presented at scientific conferences and are publicly available on the web.
